chunks.text: When Centennial Train J1 headed south from Auckland on that Saturday in April 1985,
it was just over 20 years since steam had faded from regular passenger service on the trunk.

And for many, the spectacle was a dream come true. The The The The The I'm going to be. The The The The return of steam was a colourful pageant and as many people turned out to watch the train as the 1953 royal tour.
It was a far cry from the days of black and white
seen in this national film unit classic of the commonplace
shot in 1967. Towering above the Canterbury Plains and cleaving the South Island in two, the Alps form an impressive barrier.
The rivers have sought a way through but have been trapped in large lakes or flung
away down the mountain slopes to the Tasman or the Pacific.
But man joined the two coasts. In 1906, the mountains echoed as workers flung up high spindly viaducts,
struggled to heave two pieces of steel rail across the mountains.
Christchurch wasn't connected to Greymouth until
1923 when the five mile Oterra tunnel was finished. But the viaduct spanning the gullies at
staircase, Broken River and Slovans Creek stood ready by 19009. Today they still listened
to the waters of the Waimakariri and await the trains. Steam whistles echoing down the broken river gorge,
scaring the rabbits at Avoca and Coralinn,
42 miles of mountain railway,
and all the wagons are chock-ob-block
as Westland is carried out in 600-ton trains,
cement, rainforest timber, and bituminous coal,
and cinders are still blackening the high snows as the freight is hauled out.
Between Springfield and Arthur's Pass, mountainous KB engines haul most of the tonnish.
They burn west coast coal in their huge fireboxes, and in their boilers the waters from the mountain streams.
To the ordinary traveller hurrying across an island, the Southern
Alps are a lot of grand scenery packed into a few hours. But to linger up at Cass
is to appreciate another characteristic of the region, the affinity between the hard,
tough landscape and the rugged engines which conquer it. The

and steam has been living on borrowed time for more than 10 of those years.
